title: OGM Meta: Growth, Platforms, and Identity
mainTopics: Do we want to grow? In what ways?

platformDeprecation.description: OGM simplifying from multiple platforms and standing calls down to just Thursday calls
changes: Discourse being shut down (someone else's decision)
Used to have 3-4 standing calls per week, now down to just Thursday
Multiple spin-off groups (collaboration, abundance, etc.) deprecated
Files now going to Google Drive (Jerry created, but nobody knows it exists)
OGM Wiki exists but not being used for archival
platformDeprecation.johnConfusion: New member John Warinner confused by mentions of Plex, Mattermost, various calls - difficult to navigate what's active vs deprecated

growthQuestion.description: Central question: Does OGM want to grow, or stay as intimate salon?
rickFraming: Critical question: do you want to grow or not? If not, that's fine.
Groups go through biorhythms - expansive then contracting
OGM has contracted (fewer calls, fewer platforms)
If want to grow, need deliberate onboarding (buddy system, etc.)
Inside-outside dynamic exists even in welcoming groups
Mycelial nature - spin-off affinity groups model
EXO AI group example: had fallout, morphed, got new leadership, now expanding
jerryResponse: Question is for the group, not for Jerry alone
Not focused on growth, growth, growth
Prefers calls not larger than one Zoom screen (max ~64 people)
Likes seeing everybody's faces, expressions, being convivial
Early OGM had onboarding/outreach working groups - efforts petered out
'We have lovely salons, but we don't get a lot of things done'
Other communities create bodies of work (wikis, pattern languages, code)
growthQuestion.johnAddition: Companion question: In what ways? What dimensions? What directions? Growth without intention is ridiculous.

onboardingChallenge.description: New members struggle to understand OGM structure and how to navigate
johnExperience: Mentions of Plex, Mattermost, various calls - what's active?
Hard to know where to go for what
onboardingChallenge.rickInsight: Inside-outside dynamic exists even if people on inside don't see it
onboardingChallenge.peteHeuristic: Publish what you know and see who complains or adds - discovery by doing
onboardingChallenge.peteSuggestion: Ask people you find interesting: where are you hanging out? What are you working on?

salonVsBodiesOfWork.description: OGM as conversational salon vs creating tangible outputs
jerryObservation: 'Characteristic of OGM: lovely salons, but we don't get a lot of things done'
Other communities create wikis, pattern languages, code
OGM has 'a hardy crew' that shows up regularly
Maybe this is a salon for us, maybe we want to keep it that way
Open to all suggestions, not attached to specific outcome
contextualHistory: Early OGM (2020-2021): onboarding and outreach working groups started, then petered out
Multiple standing calls (3-4/week) deprecated down to just Thursday
Spin-off affinity groups existed (exactly what Rick suggested) but Jerry stepped out of them

archivalAndIndexing.description: How to make OGM calls and content discoverable and useful
staceyValue: Pete's archive was most valuable thing for her in OGM
Found something she wrote, brought it to different community
Everyone is one degree of separation from anyone they need to know
Looks at everyone as a page in her own book
Wants calls archived so can add pieces to 'pages'
Members are important - they go to different places, make up different groups
Prefers OGM mailing list (knows rough audience) over Plex (no idea who reads)
jerryProcess: Downloads video from Zoom, uploads to YouTube, links in Brain
Posts link to Mattermost with chat, transcript, AI summary attached
Has been doing this rhythmically since Mattermost server launched
Mattermost is terrible for this - not a database, hard to fetch files
Now putting files in Google Drive, but nobody knows it exists
Never thought to create call list in OGM Wiki (in Obsidian)
Wiki may not be right structure for database/lookup/analysis
peteReflection: Plex goal: who's doing what where? Help people find out more.
Devilishly difficult to get that information from people
Not because closed-lipped, but because context-dependent ('where do I hang out? today with Jesse, is that what you mean?')
Vincent Arena example: doing amazing stuff, no time to sit around and share
Missing global 'matchmaking function' - what would friends-of-friends find interesting?
Didn't track Plex readership, didn't want to categorize people
Wanted to give people agency, not assume collective categorization
Pete no longer publishing Plex, Kevin is (with different conception)
Likes and comments would need critical mass (like Amazon, Facebook) - small group doesn't have enough throughput for statistical meaning
archivalAndIndexing.klausReminder: Used to have calendar where groups advertised themselves (open or closed), made it easy to see what's happening - like Meetup app

diversityValue.description: Value of encountering views you disagree with
alexTestimony: Feels very different from everyone: 'I don't believe I'm on the same political affiliation as you guys'
'I listen to you guys, and I think, I don't agree with that'
'But that's what I value. Because otherwise, I'm not gonna listen to anybody doesn't agree with me.'
Haven't found group who totally agrees with him - if they did, wouldn't exist
Values the diversity - most all-encompassing divergent views group
Frustrated sometimes (want to expand on topics), but can form subgroups
There's a limit how many groups you can join in one week
'I'm not right at everything' - fighting against own echo chamber
diversityValue.jerryResponse: Maybe you need to start your own movement - you're unique in your cluster of perspectives
diversityValue.alexPushback: Then that'd be my people, my ideas, my thinking - that's what I'm fighting against

toolChoicesFrustration.description: No good answer to 'what tool should we use for community?'
jerryCritique: 'Ironically, when somebody says, I've got a new community, what tool should I use? There's no good answer.'
Pete and Jerry with lots of experience: 'oh god, not this question again'
Could try Discord, Google group, this, that - all have pluses and minuses
Facebook has eaten the space, business model is addicting you - not cool
LinkedIn very business-y, private LinkedIn groups don't have much life
'I'm a little angry at the software world for not having fixed this and solved it at this point'
'We know enough about all these things to figure out what to do... but we haven't'
peopleMentioned: Vincent Arena (left to build his project entrepreneurially)
Ben Roberts (community with Kumu map of overlapping communities)

wikisVsNewsletters.description: Different topographies of online community spaces
jerryHistory: Pete and Jerry thought years ago we'd all collaborate through wikis
Semi-structured wikis (Wagon and variants) came and went
Vision: rhizomal mycelial network of connected text nodes
MassiveWiki isn't quite a wiki yet - can't click to edit page you're looking at
Don't have wiki-like conversation yet in (ironically) OGM Wiki

newsletter: Owner might see subscriber list, but not public
Can't tell if people forwarded to friends (second-order reach)
mailingList: OGM list: can see all members in Google Groups
Can see who email went to (first-order reach visible)
wiki: Usually can't see who read page (unless large like Wikipedia)
Very different feeling around shared asset

storiesShared.topic: EXO AI group fallout and rebirth
storiesShared.summary: EXO community had affiliated AI subgroup. Leadership had fallout between main group and AI subgroup. AI group went independent, then morphed with new leadership. Now expanding again. Spin-off group from AI group focused on human flourishing (Rick pushed for 'human and planetary flourishing').
storiesShared.impact: Example of mycelial spin-off groups - inhibitory and pro-growth strategies

storiesShared.summary: Group Rick used to belong to but left (apolitical, which was ironic because it wasn't really). Had ~50 different subgroups (clustering, infinities, crypto, etc.). Incredible to see breadth of affinity groups.
storiesShared.impact: Model for self-organizing, self-generating, self-governing spin-off groups

storiesShared.summary: Saddleback Church where Rick Warren was pastor. Got giant through cell structure: Colton Group, downhill bikers, etc. - little cells with common interests. Once a year all gathered in local football stadium because couldn't fit in church.
storiesShared.impact: Model for scaled community with intimate affinity cells

storiesShared.topic: Vincent Arena's 'who's doing what with whom' project
storiesShared.summary: Early OGM question: who's doing what with whom? Vincent came straight out of college (had done this for his college). Started project to map groups and members. Went entrepreneurial, built it up, went off. Still doing it. Hasn't been in OGM for quite a while.
storiesShared.impact: Example of someone taking OGM-spawned idea and building it independently

storiesShared.topic: View from the mast / Flotilla project
storiesShared.summary: Pete gave metaphor: lots of overlapping raindrop-y organizations swimming in flotilla. Side project called 'Flotilla.' If you go to top of OGM mast and look out, some orgs closer, some on horizon. Some have overlapping members who are regulars here.
storiesShared.impact: Conceptual model for understanding community adjacency

storiesShared.summary: Disney invented multi-plane camera for cartoons: layers of cells (background landscape, trees, Donald Duck) moving at different speeds to create depth illusion. Jerry wanted this for OGM: one layer = view from mast (orgs), another = people, another = projects. Could see connections between layers (Stacey in OGM and Neobooks project), turn around, pull out layers to see in 2D or see relationships. More code than anyone wanted to create.
storiesShared.impact: Aspirational model for visualizing multi-dimensional community relationships

frameworks.description: Even welcoming groups have insider perspective that's invisible to insiders but clear to newcomers

questionsRaised: Do we want to grow or not?
If we want to grow, in what ways, dimensions, directions?
How do we do deliberate onboarding (buddy system, etc.)?
How do we make OGM content discoverable and useful?
Where should call files and transcripts be stored and indexed?
Is OGM Wiki the right place for call archives?
How do we balance salon conversation with creating bodies of work?
What tools should new communities use? (Why hasn't software world solved this?)
How do we enable 'who's doing what with whom' discovery without violating privacy?
How do we create matchmaking function for friends-of-friends interests?
Should we reinstate calendar for groups to advertise themselves?
Should we re-nurture mycelial spin-off groups?
How do we value diversity of views while also having depth?
Who reads the Plex? (Stacey: do we know? are you measuring?)
Can we have likes/comments features at small scale? (Pete: not enough throughput for statistical meaning)

specialNotes: This is THE meta-call - OGM discussing OGM structure, identity, future
John Warinner as new member barometer: reveals onboarding gaps
Platform deprecation: Mattermost, Discourse, multiple standing calls → just Thursday + mailing list
Jerry's files workflow: Zoom → YouTube → Brain → Mattermost (now Google Drive) - but no good system
Central tension: growth and structure vs intimacy and salon
Alex's testimony: 'I don't agree with you guys, but that's why I value being here' - powerful
Jerry: 'We have lovely salons, but we don't get a lot of things done' - key self-assessment
Pete's privacy paradox: want matchmaking but don't want to categorize people without consent
Klaus's calendar reminder: simple solution that existed before, could reinstate
Call doesn't resolve questions - true to salon nature
